trans-unit.source: Concurrency and workload management in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Concurrency and workload management in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Understand concurrency and workload management in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Understand concurrency and workload management in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: To deliver predictable performance at scale SQL Data Warehouse implements mechanisms for managing both workload concurrency and computational resource assignment.
trans-unit.target: To deliver predictable performance at scale SQL Data Warehouse implements mechanisms for managing both workload concurrency and computational resource assignment.

trans-unit.source: This article introduces you to the concepts of concurrency and workload management; explaining how both features have been implemented and how you can control them in your data warehouse.
trans-unit.target: This article introduces you to the concepts of concurrency and workload management; explaining how both features have been implemented and how you can control them in your data warehouse.

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand that concurrency in SQL Data Warehouse is governed by two concepts; concurrent queries and concurrency slots.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand that concurrency in SQL Data Warehouse is governed by two concepts; concurrent queries and concurrency slots.

trans-unit.source: Concurrent queries equates to the number of queries executing at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Concurrent queries equates to the number of queries executing at the same time.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse supports up to 32 concurrent queries.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse supports up to 32 concurrent queries.

trans-unit.source: Each query execution counts as a single query regardless of whether it is a serial query (single threaded) or parallel query (multi-threaded).
trans-unit.target: Each query execution counts as a single query regardless of whether it is a serial query (single threaded) or parallel query (multi-threaded).

trans-unit.source: This is a fixed cap and applies to all service levels and all queries.
trans-unit.target: This is a fixed cap and applies to all service levels and all queries.

trans-unit.source: Concurrency slots is a more dynamic concept and is relative to the Data Warehouse Unit (DWU) service level objective for your data warehouse.
trans-unit.target: Concurrency slots is a more dynamic concept and is relative to the Data Warehouse Unit (DWU) service level objective for your data warehouse.

trans-unit.source: As you increase the number of DWU allocated to SQL Data Warehouse more compute resources are assigned.
trans-unit.target: As you increase the number of DWU allocated to SQL Data Warehouse more compute resources are assigned.

trans-unit.source: However, increasing DWU also increases the number of concurrency slots available.
trans-unit.target: However, increasing DWU also increases the number of concurrency slots available.

trans-unit.source: As a general rule, each concurrently executing query consumes one or more concurrency slots.
trans-unit.target: As a general rule, each concurrently executing query consumes one or more concurrency slots.

trans-unit.source: The exact number of slots depends on three factors:
trans-unit.target: The exact number of slots depends on three factors:

trans-unit.source: The DWU setting for the SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: The DWU setting for the SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: The resource class that the user belongs to
trans-unit.target: The resource class that the user belongs to

trans-unit.source: Whether the query or operation is governed by the concurrency slot model
trans-unit.target: Whether the query or operation is governed by the concurrency slot model

trans-unit.source: It is worth noting that not every query is governed by the concurrency slot query rule.
trans-unit.target: It is worth noting that not every query is governed by the concurrency slot query rule.

trans-unit.source: Some queries and operations do not consume concurrency slots at all.
trans-unit.target: Some queries and operations do not consume concurrency slots at all.

trans-unit.source: These queries and operations are still limited by the concurrent query limit which is why both rules are described.
trans-unit.target: These queries and operations are still limited by the concurrent query limit which is why both rules are described.

trans-unit.source: Please refer to the <linkText>resource class exceptions</linkText><title></title> section below for more details.
trans-unit.target: Please refer to the <linkText>resource class exceptions</linkText><title></title> section below for more details.

trans-unit.source: The table below describes the limits for both concurrent queries and concurrency slots; assuming your query is resource governed.
trans-unit.target: The table below describes the limits for both concurrent queries and concurrency slots; assuming your query is resource governed.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse query workloads have to live within these thresholds.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse query workloads have to live within these thresholds.

trans-unit.source: If there are more than 32 concurrent queries or you exceed the number of concurrency slots then the query will be queued until both thresholds can be satisfied.
trans-unit.target: If there are more than 32 concurrent queries or you exceed the number of concurrency slots then the query will be queued until both thresholds can be satisfied.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse exposes four different resource classes in the form of database roles as part of its workload management implementation.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse exposes four different resource classes in the form of database roles as part of its workload management implementation.

trans-unit.source: Resource classes are an essential part of SQL Data Warehouse workload management.
trans-unit.target: Resource classes are an essential part of SQL Data Warehouse workload management.

trans-unit.source: They govern the computational resources allocated to the query.
trans-unit.target: They govern the computational resources allocated to the query.

trans-unit.source: By default each user is a member of the small resource class - smallrc.
trans-unit.target: By default each user is a member of the small resource class - smallrc.

trans-unit.source: However, any user can be added to one or more of the higher resource classes.
trans-unit.target: However, any user can be added to one or more of the higher resource classes.

trans-unit.source: As a general rule, SQL Data Warehouse will take the highest role membership for query execution.
trans-unit.target: As a general rule, SQL Data Warehouse will take the highest role membership for query execution.

trans-unit.source: Adding a user to a higher resource class will increase the resources for that user but it will also consume greater concurrency slots; potentially limiting your concurrency.
trans-unit.target: Adding a user to a higher resource class will increase the resources for that user but it will also consume greater concurrency slots; potentially limiting your concurrency.

trans-unit.source: This is due to the fact that as more resources are allocated to one query the system needs to limit resources consumed by others.
trans-unit.target: This is due to the fact that as more resources are allocated to one query the system needs to limit resources consumed by others.

trans-unit.source: The most important resource governed by the higher resource class is memory.
trans-unit.target: The most important resource governed by the higher resource class is memory.

trans-unit.source: Most data warehouse tables of any meaningful size will be using clustered columnstore indexes.
trans-unit.target: Most data warehouse tables of any meaningful size will be using clustered columnstore indexes.

trans-unit.source: Whilst this typically provides the best performance for data warehouse workloads maintaining them is a memory intensive operation.
trans-unit.target: Whilst this typically provides the best performance for data warehouse workloads maintaining them is a memory intensive operation.

trans-unit.source: It is often highly beneficial to use the higher resource classes for data management operations such as index rebuilds.
trans-unit.target: It is often highly beneficial to use the higher resource classes for data management operations such as index rebuilds.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse has implemented resource classes through the use of database roles.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse has implemented resource classes through the use of database roles.

trans-unit.source: To become a member of a higher resource class and increase your memory simply and priority you simply add your database user to one of the roles / resource classes mentioned above.
trans-unit.target: To become a member of a higher resource class and increase your memory simply and priority you simply add your database user to one of the roles / resource classes mentioned above.

trans-unit.source: You can add and remove yourself to the workload management database role using the sp_addrolemember and sp_droprolemember procedures.
trans-unit.target: You can add and remove yourself to the workload management database role using the sp_addrolemember and sp_droprolemember procedures.

trans-unit.source: Note you will require ALTER ROLE permission to do this.
trans-unit.target: Note you will require ALTER ROLE permission to do this.

trans-unit.source: You are not able to use the ALTER ROLE DDL syntax.
trans-unit.target: You are not able to use the ALTER ROLE DDL syntax.

trans-unit.source: You must use the aforementioned stored procedures.
trans-unit.target: You must use the aforementioned stored procedures.

trans-unit.source: A full example of how to create logins and users is provided in the [managing users)[#managing-users] section at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: A full example of how to create logins and users is provided in the [managing users)[#managing-users] section at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: Rather than adding a user into and out of a workload management group it is often simpler to initiate those more intensive operations through a separate login/user that is permanently assigned to the higher resource class.
trans-unit.target: Rather than adding a user into and out of a workload management group it is often simpler to initiate those more intensive operations through a separate login/user that is permanently assigned to the higher resource class.

trans-unit.source: The following table details the increase in memory available to each query; subject to the resource class applied to the user executing it:
trans-unit.target: The following table details the increase in memory available to each query; subject to the resource class applied to the user executing it:

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, as mentioned above, the higher the resource class assigned to the user the greater the concurrency slot consumption.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, as mentioned above, the higher the resource class assigned to the user the greater the concurrency slot consumption.

trans-unit.source: The following table documents the consumption of concurrency slots by queries in a given resource class.
trans-unit.target: The following table documents the consumption of concurrency slots by queries in a given resource class.

trans-unit.source: There are occasions where membership of a higher resource class does not alter the resources assigned to the query or operation.
trans-unit.target: There are occasions where membership of a higher resource class does not alter the resources assigned to the query or operation.

trans-unit.source: Typically this occurs when the resources required to fulfil the action are low.
trans-unit.target: Typically this occurs when the resources required to fulfil the action are low.

trans-unit.source: In these cases the default or small resource class (smallrc) is always used irrespective of the resource class assigned to the user.
trans-unit.target: In these cases the default or small resource class (smallrc) is always used irrespective of the resource class assigned to the user.

trans-unit.source: As an example, CREATE LOGIN will always run in the smallrc.
trans-unit.target: As an example, CREATE LOGIN will always run in the smallrc.

trans-unit.source: The resources required to fulfil this operation are very low and so it would not make sense to include the query in the concurrency slot model.
trans-unit.target: The resources required to fulfil this operation are very low and so it would not make sense to include the query in the concurrency slot model.

trans-unit.source: It would be wasteful to pre-allocate large amounts of memory for this action.
trans-unit.target: It would be wasteful to pre-allocate large amounts of memory for this action.

trans-unit.source: By excluding CREATE LOGIN from the concurrency slot model SQL Data Warehouse can be much more efficient.
trans-unit.target: By excluding CREATE LOGIN from the concurrency slot model SQL Data Warehouse can be much more efficient.

trans-unit.source: Below is a list of statements and operations that are governed by resource classes:
trans-unit.target: Below is a list of statements and operations that are governed by resource classes:

trans-unit.source: It is worth highlighting that SELECT queries executing exclusively against dynamic management views and catalog views are not governed by resource classes.
trans-unit.target: It is worth highlighting that SELECT queries executing exclusively against dynamic management views and catalog views are not governed by resource classes.

trans-unit.source: It is important to remember that the majority of end user queries are likely to be governed by resource classes.
trans-unit.target: It is important to remember that the majority of end user queries are likely to be governed by resource classes.

trans-unit.source: The general rule is that the active query workload must fit inside both the concurrent query and concurrency slot thresholds unless it has been specifically excluded by the platform.
trans-unit.target: The general rule is that the active query workload must fit inside both the concurrent query and concurrency slot thresholds unless it has been specifically excluded by the platform.

trans-unit.source: As an end user you cannot choose to exclude a query from the concurrency slot model.
trans-unit.target: As an end user you cannot choose to exclude a query from the concurrency slot model.

trans-unit.source: Once either threshold has been exceeded queries will begin to queue.
trans-unit.target: Once either threshold has been exceeded queries will begin to queue.

trans-unit.source: Queued queries will be addressed in priority order followed by submission time.
trans-unit.target: Queued queries will be addressed in priority order followed by submission time.

trans-unit.source: Under the covers of SQL Data Warehouse's workload management things are a little bit more complicated.
trans-unit.target: Under the covers of SQL Data Warehouse's workload management things are a little bit more complicated.

trans-unit.source: The resource classes are dynamically mapped to a generic set of workload management groups within resource governor.
trans-unit.target: The resource classes are dynamically mapped to a generic set of workload management groups within resource governor.

trans-unit.source: The groups used will depend on the DWU value for the warehouse.
trans-unit.target: The groups used will depend on the DWU value for the warehouse.

trans-unit.source: However, there are total of eight workload groups used by SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: However, there are total of eight workload groups used by SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: These 8 groups map across to the concurrency slot consumption
trans-unit.target: These 8 groups map across to the concurrency slot consumption

trans-unit.source: So, for example, if DW500 is the current DWU setting for your SQL Data Warehouse then the active workload groups would be mapped to the resource classes as follows:
trans-unit.target: So, for example, if DW500 is the current DWU setting for your SQL Data Warehouse then the active workload groups would be mapped to the resource classes as follows:

trans-unit.target: To look at the differences in memory resource allocation in detail from the perspective of the resource governor use the following query:

trans-unit.source: The query above can also be used to analyse active and historic usage of the workload groups when troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: The query above can also be used to analyse active and historic usage of the workload groups when troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: This section provides some additional examples to work through for managing users and detecting queries that are queuing.
trans-unit.target: This section provides some additional examples to work through for managing users and detecting queries that are queuing.

trans-unit.source: To grant access to a user to the SQL Data Warehouse they will first need a login.
trans-unit.target: To grant access to a user to the SQL Data Warehouse they will first need a login.

trans-unit.source: Open a connection to the master database for your SQL Data Warehouse and execute the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Open a connection to the master database for your SQL Data Warehouse and execute the following commands:

trans-unit.source: it is a good idea to create users for your logins in the master database for when working with both Azure SQL database and SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: it is a good idea to create users for your logins in the master database for when working with both Azure SQL database and SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: There are two server roles available at this level that require the login to have a user in master in order to grant membership.
trans-unit.target: There are two server roles available at this level that require the login to have a user in master in order to grant membership.

trans-unit.source: In both Azure SQL database and SQL Data Warehouse these roles grant rights to manage logins and to create databases.
trans-unit.target: In both Azure SQL database and SQL Data Warehouse these roles grant rights to manage logins and to create databases.

trans-unit.source: This is different to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: This is different to SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: For more details please refer to the [Managing Databases and Logins in Azure SQL Database] article for more details.
trans-unit.target: For more details please refer to the [Managing Databases and Logins in Azure SQL Database] article for more details.

trans-unit.source: Once the login has been created then a user account now needs to be added.
trans-unit.target: Once the login has been created then a user account now needs to be added.

trans-unit.source: Open a connection to the SQL Data Warehouse database and execute the following command:
trans-unit.target: Open a connection to the SQL Data Warehouse database and execute the following command:

trans-unit.source: Once complete permissions will need to be granted to the user.
trans-unit.target: Once complete permissions will need to be granted to the user.

trans-unit.source: The example below grants CONTROL on the SQL Data Warehouse database.
trans-unit.target: The example below grants CONTROL on the SQL Data Warehouse database.

trans-unit.source: CONTROL at the database level is the equivalent of db_owner in SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: CONTROL at the database level is the equivalent of db_owner in SQL Server.

trans-unit.target: To see the workload management roles use the following query:

trans-unit.target: To add a user to an increase workload management role use the following query:

trans-unit.target: To remove a user from an workload management role use the following query:

trans-unit.source: It is not possible to remove a user from the smallrc.
trans-unit.target: It is not possible to remove a user from the smallrc.

trans-unit.source: To see which users are members of a given role use the following query:
trans-unit.target: To see which users are members of a given role use the following query:

trans-unit.source: To identify queries that are held in a concurrency queue you can always refer to the sys.dm_pdw_exec_requests DMV.
trans-unit.target: To identify queries that are held in a concurrency queue you can always refer to the sys.dm_pdw_exec_requests DMV.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse has specific wait types for measuring concurrency.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse has specific wait types for measuring concurrency.

trans-unit.source: The LocalQueriesConcurrencyResourceType refers to queries that sit outside of the concurrency slot framework.
trans-unit.target: The LocalQueriesConcurrencyResourceType refers to queries that sit outside of the concurrency slot framework.

trans-unit.source: DMV queries and system functions such as SELECT @@VERSION are examples of local queries.
trans-unit.target: DMV queries and system functions such as SELECT @@VERSION are examples of local queries.

trans-unit.source: The UserConcurrencyResourceType refers to queries that sit inside the concurrency slot framework.
trans-unit.target: The UserConcurrencyResourceType refers to queries that sit inside the concurrency slot framework.

trans-unit.source: Queries against end user tables represent examples which would use this resource type.
trans-unit.target: Queries against end user tables represent examples which would use this resource type.

trans-unit.source: The DmsConcurrencyResourceType refers to waits resulting from data movement operations.
trans-unit.target: The DmsConcurrencyResourceType refers to waits resulting from data movement operations.

trans-unit.source: The BackupConcurrencyResourceType can be seen when a database is being backed up.
trans-unit.target: The BackupConcurrencyResourceType can be seen when a database is being backed up.

trans-unit.source: The maximum value for this resource type is 1.
trans-unit.target: The maximum value for this resource type is 1.

trans-unit.source: If multiple backups have been requested at the same time the others will queue.
trans-unit.target: If multiple backups have been requested at the same time the others will queue.

trans-unit.source: To perform analysis of currently queued queries to find out what resources a request is waiting for please refer to the sys.dm_pdw_waits DMV.
trans-unit.target: To perform analysis of currently queued queries to find out what resources a request is waiting for please refer to the sys.dm_pdw_waits DMV.

trans-unit.source: To view just the resource waits consumed by a given query you can refer to the sys.dm_pdw_resource_waits DMV.
trans-unit.target: To view just the resource waits consumed by a given query you can refer to the sys.dm_pdw_resource_waits DMV.

trans-unit.source: Resource wait time only measures the time waiting for resources to be provided as opposed to signal wait time which is the time it takes for the underlying SQL Server's to schedule the query onto the CPU.
trans-unit.target: Resource wait time only measures the time waiting for resources to be provided as opposed to signal wait time which is the time it takes for the underlying SQL Server's to schedule the query onto the CPU.

trans-unit.source: Finally, for historic trend analysis of waits then SQL Datawarehouse provides the sys.dm_pdw_wait_stats DMV.
trans-unit.target: Finally, for historic trend analysis of waits then SQL Datawarehouse provides the sys.dm_pdw_wait_stats DMV.

trans-unit.target: For more development tips, see <linkText>development overview</linkText><title></title>.
